Development Studies (Human Development T.status_quo: For two decades, except for 2008 and 2022 (years of major global financial and market downturns), global average wealth per adult has tended to rise modestly year-over-year, typically in the low single digits, in line with steady financial market appreciation, asset value increases, and modest real economic growth.

perspective_derived_factors.effect: Increases probability: Wealth per adult is highly sensitive to global equity and real estate performance. 2024 saw strong US/global markets (S&P500 up, real estate stable or rising in most markets), benefiting global average wealth.

Decreases probability slightly: Strength or weakness in the US dollar can meaningfully affect cross-country USD-denominated wealth stats. In 2024, the dollar was somewhat stronger, tempering local gains in non-USD markets.

Mixed effect: Nominal wealth values can rise even in high-inflation environments, but real wealth gains may be limited or negative in some regions. For global averages, high inflation in EMEA/Emerging Markets offset by asset appreciation in US, and local currency declines diminish USD gains elsewhere.

Neutral to slight decrease: Rising number of adults can lower average wealth per adult if wealth creation doesn’t keep pace. 2024’s demographic data show growth in regions with both rising and falling wealth, but not enough to reverse global gains.

Mixed/slightly increases: Most wealth growth is concentrated among the wealthiest and in high-income countries, which lifts the global average. Even as median gains are modest or stagnant, surges in the top percentiles lift averages. UBS/UBI reports suggest middle and upper wealth tiers drove 2024 gains.

Mixed: Strong Americas/North America, solid APAC growth (Taiwan, S. Korea, Australia), weaker EMEA and some EMs. Half of surveyed markets saw declines, but large wealthy countries (US, Switzerland, etc.) outweighed declines elsewhere in arithmetic average calculations.

Strongly increases probability: All major UBS/market reports state global wealth per adult increased by approximately 4.6% in 2024, driven by double-digit USD gains in the Americas, despite some negative growth in EMEA/non-core APAC.

Development Studies (Human Development T.no_scenario: Global markets crash (not seen in 2024), or a strong US dollar sharply devalues non-USD assets, or major demographic shifts (huge growth in adult population with little or negative wealth accrual in populous regions). Data surprises from WID sharply revise global growth estimates down, perhaps by a different asset or valuation methodology, causing headline values to appear lower or flat.
Development Studies (Human Development T.yes_scenario: Global equities, property values, and major asset classes all trend upward or stay resilient (as happened in 2024), especially in the US (which holds nearly 40% of global HNW individuals), meaning wealth increases among the rich pull up the global average per adult. Even if half the world's countries see local declines, gains in the Americas/North America, as confirmed by UBS, outweigh losses in poorer or weaker regions.
Development Studies (Human Development T.final_reasoning: The base rate for annual global average wealth gain, except during systemic crisis years (such as 2008, 2022), is positive and in the low single digits. All major 2024 reports (UBS, Invezz, Forbes, Vanguardia) highlight a 4.6% global wealth per adult increase for 2024, led by North America and supported by strong US equity/property markets. About half of surveyed markets saw nominal declines, but, crucially, the global average is mostly driven by wealthy economies where assets and population are concentrated (US, Switzerland, North America). Reports emphasize increases in both total millionaires and 'middle class' millionaires, with broad-based asset price appreciation. No egregious global currency, economic, or asset collapses occurred in 2024 to offset these gains. While eurozone/EMEA and parts of Asia underperformed or had declines due to currency moves or inflation, this was entirely offset at the global scale. Given the available evidence, strong alignment among several independent wealth trackers, and the long-run base rate, the probability is extremely high.
